node.text: The fast-spreading #deltavariant is raising fresh health concerns even in places where Covid vaccination rates are high. Senior pharmaceuticals analyst Sam Fazeli is here to tell you what you need to know.

node.title: Your Biggest Delta Variant Questions Answered

node.text:
"Donald Trump upended the American presidency after stepping away from the company that made him rich and famous. Four years later, returning to his empire after losing the White House, what he finds may upend him," write Sophie Alexander and Max Abelson.

"Three quarters of Trump's net worth is tied up in urban real estate. And urban real estate has been hammered by Covid-19," Tim O'Brien tells @quicktake's Tim Stenovec.

The former president's net worth is down to $2.3 billion from $3 billion in 2016. The pandemic he promised would disappear is walloping his company, and the riot that got him impeached for a second time is wounding his brand.

Check out "Trump’s Ailing Empire" on bloomberg.com/graphics to see just how deep in peril he really is.

node.text:
👻 Snap Inc. is rolling out a new tool for its Snapchat app to feature popular videos, called Spotlight, and said it will pay out $1 million a day to creators of the top-performing posts. How good of a deal is that?

🤳🏻 "The more remarkable thing about Snap is that it wasn't offering these sort of incentives to people to create good content previously."

Alex Webb joined @quicktake's Tim Steno to explain why Snap decided to compensate viral creators.

#snapchat #influencer #app #creators #snap

node.title: Snapchat to Pay $1 Million a Day to Creators

node.text:
It’s been 20 months since a pair of fatal crashes forced regulators around the globe to ground the once top-selling jet. The FAA finally approved the Max to resume commercial flights today, which will allow Boeing to make money off the roughly 450 Max jets it has built but not yet delivered.

After the longest grounding of an aircraft in modern U.S. history, it’s reasonable to ask whether the plane is safe. Bloomberg Opinion columnists Chris Bryant and Brooke Sutherland teamed up to discuss the future of the Max, and whether or not they'd be willing to board one.

#Boeing #Boeing737 #737max #airplane #aircraft #airline #southwest #americanair #flight #pandemic #livestream #video #igtv #travel

node.title: Boeing’s 737 Max Is Back. Are You Willing to Board?

node.text:
Frank Barry didn’t ask a soul about Donald Trump or Joe Biden on his @looking4lincoln trip. For the two months he spent crossing the country along the Lincoln Highway by Winnebago, talking with Americans and hoping to reach San Francisco by Election Day, he never brought up the campaign. Sometimes he knew how people felt — occasionally they would say, though usually not. But it didn’t matter. He wasn’t running a focus group. He was trying to catch glimpses of a more enduring spirit, the kind that has transcended parties and generations, the kind that lives, as Lincoln said, in the better angels of our nature. And maybe those glimpses could help us see more of ourselves in each other, and in the land we share.

#lincolnhighway #travel #rv #roadtrip #winnebago #highway #ontheroad #interview #video

node.title: The End of the Lincoln Highway

node.text:
“It was really impossible not to feel the immediacy, the urgency of climate change on this leg of the trip.”

Frank Barry stops in #Iowa and #Colorado, continuing his journey across the U.S. along the Lincoln Highway.

Video by @quicktake, footage by @looking4lincoln.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 06, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text.

node.text:
💉 Vaccines aren't consumer products. They're infrastructure, writes David Fickling. 

The growing evidence that the efficacy of Covid-19 vaccines is declining over time should be a cause of worry for most of us. For the drug companies that have spent billions of dollars developing them, it’s a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.

Recent studies on vaccine effectiveness have led to a run of orders for boosters in recent weeks. Demand for booster shots and delta’s infectiousness have made manufacturing shots a good opportunity for the pharmaceutical industry.

That’s quite a shift for the traditional vaccine business model. Vaccinations have traditionally been an unprofitable backwater for the pharmaceutical industry.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'ltching toreinvent your career? Nowisthetime Job openings level for nonfarm employment 0.08 0.06 0.04 0.02 2000 2005 2010 Note:Inthousandsofpersons, seasonally adjusted thousandso Reserve Bank ofS Louis 2015 0.00 2020 BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
How much are people reevaluating their careers, and what do they want out of work these days? The answers to those questions could have a profound impact on the labor market recovery, writes Conor Sen.

There's reason to be a little skeptical when we hear that people, particularly younger people, are going to reimagine something as fundamental as employment in the wake of an economic shock. There were similar ideas following the 2008 recession that didn't hold up in reality.

We've been long overdue for a societal reevaluation of work as technology has blurred the lines between the office and the home. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 05, 2021. May be an image of car and text that says 'BMW could soon make Vcouldsoonmakemorequality more and affordable cars in China BMW X2 BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
🚗 BMW has a knack for timing its China investments.

BMW’s China unit is close to a deal to buy production assets worth $252 million from the parent of its main partner, Brilliance Auto. The move is a clever one, especially now, writes Anjani Trivedi. 

With this potential purchase, the German company can make more quality cars at increasingly affordable prices. That’s in keeping with Beijing’s focus on “common prosperity,” or a more equitable distribution of incomes across the country.

The plan to address regional, urban-rural and income gaps matters for automakers, as Beijing’s proclamation is likely to affect how consumers make and spend their money.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says '"Sure, message me on Signal," says barely anyone, ever Cumulative change in daily active users WhatsApp Telegram Signal 100% -50 Feb Jan 2021 Source:Apptopia Mar Apr May -100 Jul Jun Aug BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Elon Musk instructing his 42 million Twitter followers to use Signal wasn't enough to get people to actually use Signal.

After rising to 13 million daily active users at the start of the year, Signal's user base has since fallen to 5 million. In contrast, Facebook-owned WhatsApp has been downloaded onto more than six billion devices and more than half a billion people on Earth use WhatsApp everyday.

Parmy Olson explains: "WhatsApp’s growth is not just driven by consumer tastes. It’s fueled by the social infrastructure that billions of people have created over more than a decade."

Tap the link in our bio to read more.

#signal #elonmusk #whatsapp #telegram

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Can you solve our virtual escape room puzzle? After picking up the goods, first thing you Should do is call me. My number is encoded In our usval way. Reflect on it and get In touch ASAP 1 8ठठ ಅಿਠ M162 VH'.

node.text:
One of the most extraordinary puzzle innovations of the last year has been the rise of virtual escape rooms. We've teamed up with @theescapegame to make our very own. Ready? Then let’s dive in:

International art thieves have struck again!

🖼 Following the theft of Monet’s “Water Lilies” last week, art thieves broke into the The Magura Museum of Fine Arts and stole another painting. We managed to capture the thief and recover the painting. It appears that he was scheduled to drop off the piece with his contact at midnight on Thursday, September 9. They’re supposed to meet at an intersection near the Barclay Museum, but we don’t know precisely which one. If we figure out the location before then, we can get there ourselves and hopefully catch a glimpse of the contact.

Can you figure out where the drop is supposed to take place?

📃The first clue is the pictured note. Tap the link in our bio for the other two clues. 📞 Oh, and don't be afraid to call for help.

#puzzle #escaperoom #heist

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 04, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Daily Covid cases Indonesia Southeast Asia desperately needs Covid vaccines 60K Malaysia 40 30K Philippines 30K 20 20 10 Mar 2020 Jan 2021 Mar 2020 Vietnam Jan 2021 Mar 2020 20K Thailand Jan 2021 30K Myanmar 8K 20 Mar 2020 Jan 2021 o Mar 2020 Source: Our Worldi Jan 2021 Mar Jan 2020 2021 BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Southeast Asia is a vital region of 670 million on China’s doorstep. From the beginning, it been a crucial vaccine battleground, with all sides jostling for influence. But it’s also now in desperate need.

After a promising start last year, a variant-fueled surge has battered the region over the past few months.

🇻🇳Vietnam, which had no deaths for the first months of the pandemic and contained infections for much of 2020 despite bordering China, has now gone from less than 1,000 daily cases in early July to more than 12 times that by early this month, forcing a draconian lockdown of Ho Chi Minh City. Less than 3% of the population is fully vaccinated.

🇮🇩Indonesia, meanwhile, is now coming out of its latest devastating wave but has completely immunized just over 13%.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the winners or losers of vaccine diplomacy.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 04, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'If you want your kid to become the next Zuckerberg, don't take away their video games BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
China is not a fan of video games. Earlier this week, a government agency announced new rules that would restrict the time that minors’ can play online games to about three hours a week. But are games really so dangerous to young minds? Tae Kim doesn't think so.

"Powerful technology titans have credited video games for putting them on a path to success," writes Kim. In 2015, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said he would never have gotten into programming if he hadn’t played games when he was younger, adding that his passion for making games developed his technical skills.

And it’s not just coding. Gaming can help people advance in their professional careers. Shopify CEO Tobi Lutke said he has learned more about effectively running a business from playing Starcraft than he ever attained from reading books.

Tap the link in our bio to read Kim's full defense of gaming.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 04, 2021. May be an image of map and text that says 'Here's where U.S. vaccine donations have been donationshavebeengoingsofar going No. of vaccine doses donated 2 4 6M Note:AsofAugust3. August3. Note: Asof Source: White House BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
The U.S. has donated Covid vaccines to more than 60 beneficiaries so far.

That's great, but it's not good enough. The 100 million or so doses handed out so far is only about 40% of the total amount that the U.S. has pledged to give by the end of the year. Plus, you have to ask, when the likes of Senegal and Afghanistan are in desperate need of doses, does Canada really need to dip into the COVAX supply?

Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 03, 2021. May be an image of road and text that says 'India's world- beating GDP cannot mask the pain of the Covid pandemic'.

node.text:
By focusing on a V-shaped recovery, policy makers are ignoring the damaging consequences for India’s long-term competitiveness, writes Andy Mukherjee. 

Officials have been quick to parade last quarter’s 20% growth as vindication of their prediction of “imminent V-shaped recovery.” The number policy makers should focus on is minus 20%, for that’s the shortfall in production from India’s pre-coronavirus growth path.

India's economy was slowing even before the Covid-19 pandemic. The distribution of the income pie has changed in the past year. 

By firing workers, cutting wages and squeezing small suppliers, large firms have improved their share, repaid debt and strengthened their balance sheets. But the gains for India Inc. and the stock-owning rich have come at the expense of households and tiny enterprises.

node.text:
🌧️Elsa, Henri, Ida — It sure seems like a lot of “once-in-a-lifetimes” for one summer.

"This is the increasingly everyday reality of climate change. Wet storms are becoming wetter, and floods have become larger and more frequent in many parts of the country," writes Tara Lachapelle.

"Once in a lifetime” isn’t the right description — although perhaps it fits for the business opportunity presented by this extreme new world. Climate change is here, and it’s already costing us.

Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.text:
🏙️ Population growth may no longer be the best way to measure the health of U.S. cities.

What look like the “best places to live” may not, in fact, be the best places to live, writes Pete Saunders.

Surprisingly, a handful of Rust Belt metros — Chicago, Detroit, Cleveland and Pittsburgh, among others — outpaced the average per capita GDP gains yet actually lost population.

What’s going on? Tap the link in our bio to tune into a LIVE Clubhouse discussion on the topic.

node.text:
Across the world, poor countries are waiting for vaccines.

While wealthy nations have vaccinated tens of millions of their own people, they’ve fallen short on rescuing those in need. Parts of the West have begun planning the distribution of booster shots for their populations, a move that could intensify vaccine inequality. Out of more than 5 billion doses distributed globally, only 0.3% were in low-income nations.

@lararhiannon writes: "The U.S. and others have pledged to donate millions of vaccines, but progress is painfully slow. The U.S. and China are the closest to meeting their targets, having already delivered about 40% of their promised totals this year. With just four months left in 2021, it’s clear that pledges will not be fulfilled by the end-of-year deadline without a rapid acceleration in donations."

Tap the link in our bio to read more about vaccine inequality.
